metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: HPLC for separation, identification, and quantification of organic compounds

hplc-basics.name: HPLC Basics
hplc-basics.correct: HPLC uses a liquid mobile phase under high pressure to carry sample through a stationary phase column

uses gas as mobile phase.error: Confusing HPLC with GC - HPLC uses liquid mobile phase
uses gas as mobile phase.fix: HPLC = High-Performance LIQUID Chromatography; uses liquid solvent as mobile phase
uses gas as mobile phase.action: HPLC = liquid mobile phase; GC = gas mobile phase

operates at atmospheric pressure.error: Missing the 'high-performance' aspect - HPLC uses high pressure
operates at atmospheric pressure.fix: HPLC uses high pressure (up to 400 bar) to push liquid through the column quickly
operates at atmospheric pressure.action: High pressure enables faster analysis and better separation

separation occurs based on mass only.error: HPLC separates by polarity/affinity, not mass
separation occurs based on mass only.fix: HPLC separation depends on compound interactions with stationary and mobile phases
separation occurs based on mass only.action: Polarity, size, and intermolecular forces determine retention

persistent.gap: Not understanding HPLC as liquid chromatography under high pressure
persistent.action: Focus on: high pressure + liquid mobile phase + column stationary phase

reverse-phase.name: Reverse-Phase HPLC
reverse-phase.correct: Reverse-phase HPLC uses non-polar stationary phase and polar mobile phase

polar stationary phase.fix: Reverse-phase has non-polar stationary phase (e.g., C18); polar mobile phase
polar stationary phase.action: Reverse-phase is most common: non-polar column, polar solvent

non-polar mobile phase.error: Confusing phases - reverse-phase uses polar mobile phase
non-polar mobile phase.fix: Reverse-phase mobile phase is polar (water/acetonitrile or water/methanol)
non-polar mobile phase.action: Remember 'reverse': non-polar column, polar solvent (opposite of normal-phase)

polar compounds elute last.fix: In reverse-phase, polar compounds elute first (less retained by non-polar column)
polar compounds elute last.action: Non-polar compounds stick to non-polar column longer

persistent.action: Reverse-phase: polar compounds elute first, non-polar compounds elute last

retention-time.name: Retention Time
retention-time.correct: Retention time is the time for a compound to travel through the column and reach the detector

time in the detector.error: Confusing detection time with column time
time in the detector.fix: Retention time = time from injection to detection peak maximum
time in the detector.action: Retention time includes column travel time, not just detector response

same for all compounds.fix: Each compound has characteristic retention time based on its interactions with the column
same for all compounds.action: Different retention times allow separation and identification

independent of conditions.fix: Retention time depends on mobile phase, column, flow rate, and temperature
independent of conditions.action: Compare retention times only under identical HPLC conditions

persistent.gap: Not recognising retention time as compound-specific under defined conditions
persistent.action: Retention time identifies compounds but only under identical method conditions

identification.name: Compound Identification
identification.correct: Compounds are identified by comparing retention times with known standards

identified by peak height.fix: Retention time identifies compounds; peak area quantifies them
identified by peak height.action: Position on x-axis = identity; peak size = quantity

no standards needed.error: Missing the need for reference compounds
no standards needed.fix: Identification requires running known standards under the same conditions
no standards needed.action: Retention time only meaningful when compared to standard

one peak per compound always.fix: Compounds with similar properties may co-elute (same retention time)
one peak per compound always.action: May need to adjust method or use different detection to resolve co-eluting peaks

persistent.gap: Not understanding standard comparison for identification
persistent.action: Match sample retention time to standard retention time under identical conditions

peak-area.name: Peak Area
peak-area.correct: Peak area is proportional to the amount of compound and used for quantification

peak height determines amount.error: Using height instead of area - area is more reliable
peak height determines amount.fix: Peak area is preferred for quantification as it's less affected by peak shape variations
peak height determines amount.action: Area = integral under peak curve; more accurate than height

area directly gives concentration.fix: Peak area must be converted to concentration using a calibration curve

area independent of detector response.fix: Different compounds may have different detector responses; calibration corrects for this
area independent of detector response.action: Calibration with each analyte accounts for response differences

persistent.gap: Not using peak area correctly for quantification
persistent.action: Peak area is proportional to amount; use calibration curve to convert to concentration

calibration-curve.name: Calibration Curve
calibration-curve.correct: A calibration curve relates peak area to concentration using known standards

one standard is sufficient.fix: Multiple standards at different concentrations needed to establish linear relationship
one standard is sufficient.action: Use at least 3-5 standards spanning expected concentration range

calibration lasts forever.fix: Calibration should be repeated regularly as instrument response can change
calibration lasts forever.action: Run fresh calibration standards with each batch of samples

extrapolation is reliable.fix: Only interpolate within the calibrated concentration range
extrapolation is reliable.action: Sample concentration should fall within the standard range

persistent.gap: Not correctly using calibration curves for quantification
persistent.action: Plot peak area vs concentration for standards; use line equation for unknowns

mobile-phase.name: Mobile Phase
mobile-phase.correct: The mobile phase carries the sample through the column; its composition affects separation

composition doesn't matter.error: Ignoring mobile phase role in separation
composition doesn't matter.fix: Mobile phase polarity and composition directly affect retention times
composition doesn't matter.action: Changing mobile phase changes how compounds interact with the column

pure water always used.fix: Mobile phase is often a mixture (e.g., water/acetonitrile) that can be adjusted
pure water always used.action: Gradient elution changes mobile phase composition during the run

mobile phase is recycled without treatme.fix: HPLC requires high-purity solvents to avoid interference and column damage
mobile phase is recycled without treatme.action: Use HPLC-grade solvents; filter and degas before use

persistent.gap: Not recognising mobile phase importance in HPLC separation
persistent.action: Mobile phase composition determines how fast compounds move through the column

detector.name: HPLC Detector
detector.correct: Detectors measure compounds as they elute from the column; UV detection is most common

mass is directly measured.fix: Standard HPLC detectors measure absorbance or other properties, not mass directly
mass is directly measured.action: UV detector measures light absorption; MS detector measures mass (HPLC-MS)

all compounds detected equally.fix: UV detectors only detect compounds that absorb UV light; response varies
all compounds detected equally.action: Choose detector based on analyte properties (UV, fluorescence, refractive index)

no signal processing needed.fix: Detector signal is processed to generate chromatogram and integrate peaks
no signal processing needed.action: Software integrates peaks and calculates areas from detector signal

persistent.gap: Not understanding detector role in HPLC analysis
persistent.action: Detector converts compound presence into measurable signal for chromatogram

explanations.hplc-basics: HPLC uses liquid mobile phase under high pressure to separate compounds through a column containing stationary phase.
explanations.reverse-phase: Reverse-phase HPLC uses non-polar stationary phase and polar mobile phase; polar compounds elute first.
explanations.retention-time: Retention time is the time from injection to detection; characteristic for each compound under defined conditions.
explanations.identification: Compounds are identified by comparing retention times with known standards run under identical conditions.
explanations.peak-area: Peak area is proportional to compound amount and is used for quantification with a calibration curve.
explanations.calibration-curve: Calibration curves plot peak area vs concentration for standards; unknown concentrations are interpolated.
explanations.mobile-phase: Mobile phase composition affects separation; gradient elution changes composition during the run.
explanations.detector: Detectors measure compounds as they elute; UV is most common but choice depends on analyte properties.
